review_title: IMHO, the best space flight game for VR
one_reviews_text:
I've been playing Elite Dangerous since the first year it was released.  I've played it in VR on and off over the past 18 months.  (My total game time is over 2000 hours.)  I'm only going to review my VR experience, but I need to at least add that Elite Dangerous is not for everyone.  Even with the tutorials and "newbie" area, anticipate at least 25-50 hours of game play before "getting into the groove."   If you're still interested after hearing this, you may have "the right stuff."  

The official VR rating is "intense" but the only "intense" play I've encountered was during a very rough drive in my SRV one day.  A few VR options exist to reduce this kind of "intensity."  I now have those options enabled (!) and I haven't had a problem again.

I don't recommend trying to play this game with VR controllers. There are just too many controls. I suppose if you are very determined to use them, then install VoiceAttack which adds voice-activated commands and macros.   The best experience (IMHO) is to play using a HOTAS (e.g. ThrustMaster 16000M + TWCS Throttle) and use VoiceAttack.

The most clunky VR implementation (again IMHO) is with the galaxy and system maps. Maybe I'm more used to using my mouse when I'm not using VR, but navigating around the maps in VR feels cumbersome.

Final thoughts: Frontier recently announced their Odyssey expansion (release ETA is early 2021).  At this time it has been said VR will not initially be supported for it.   There are more details Frontier needs to reveal, but it can be safely assumed they aren't removing VR completely from the game. (that would be silly)  All we know at this time is that Odyssey is going to add first person shooter gameplay. (Honestly, at this time it isn't confirmed what else it adds.)   I personally will never attempt (again) to play a FPS combat game in VR.  I tried once and felt sick for several hours.  (I'm not talking about something like Robo Recall -- that's a lot of fun with no dizziness.)

This can be a difficult game to recommend, since it's relatively niche, but if you're into flying a space ship at all and have a VR headset it's pretty much a must-buy.  

I've played since 2015, so I've accumulated various nitpicks over the years-- it's grindy (though much less grindy than it used to be), it takes time to learn for most folks (though they've really improved the new player experience), and there's always "more" ya want from the game and new features you'll want added (though it's been updated regularly and a big update is coming in 2020).  

Even with its flaws, it's an awesome game and the best "space game" available.  The flight model is terrific, great detail in the ships and how customizable they are, a wide range of activities, enormous scale with real-life-sized planets and a full 1:1 scale Milky Way, really fun combat... it's a game I'll take a few months off from and then jump right back in and play nonstop, and there's not really anything else that can compete with it in VR.

It goes on sale regularly and when it's on sale it's one of the best deals in all of gaming considering it's a VR title more than capable of giving you hundreds of hours of gameplay.  Some folks just ain't going to be into the pace of it, nor be willing to learn the basics in the first few hours, so I always recommend new players to watch unedited streams and whatnot so you get an idea of what it's like.  I mentioned before it's a full scale galaxy, and that is meant literally, so travel time can take a while in some situations (they're situations you can avoid though... you don't NEED to travel thousands of light years or out to that far flung station that takes an hour to get to if you don't want to).  

To me, it's a great mix of simulation and arcadey action.  Be sure to do the tutorials, the recently added new player experience stuff, get to a point where you can dock and undock easily enough (doesn't have to be perfect), and then just give everything a try.

Elite Dangerous is not a casual game to play, at first. The controls are not obvious, and don't lend themselves very well to the touch controllers. There's a lot to learn, and even after becoming a "Pioneer" in exploration (a high rank), there are still things I haven't had time to figure out or master. There is a long way to go for me, yet!

Play this with your friends if you can. There's a lot of things which seem negative on the surface to say about Elite: it's best played with a HOTAS, it takes a while to figure out (and rebind) the controls and learn the game, it can feel like a grind when you're just trying to get the next bigger ship, and evidently the game doesn't support colossal pvp space battles like EVE due to networking architecture, and those things are all somewhat true.

However, there is no other game or experience quite like Elite Dangerous. The only two games in the same category are No Man's Sky and Star Citizen, neither of which support VR at the time of this review. Elite Dangerous is quite a bit different than both. It's a MMORPG with a community and missions to complete. But it can be played in "Solo" mode, which hides other human players from directly interacting with you.

Elite spaceships are a pleasure to maneouver with a HOTAS, unlike Star Citizen spaceships, which are designed with keyboard and mouse in mind at the expense of the HOTAS (to date). There's really nothing else like Elite. If you want an enormous game to fly a spaceship around, in VR, it's pretty much the only one.

I've played other VR space games which are much better for casual gaming. House of the Dying Sun is phenomenal with an X-Box controller (or touch controllers), and is a dogfighting game. Depending on your preferred control system (HOTAS or controller), mileage varies for different games. But all the other VR space games are more arena fighter games (which you can do in Elite, although it is complicated in Elite).

review_title: Best game in VR, best Space Sim game
one_reviews_text:
Elite Dangerous by itself, outside of VR, is a very good game (4/5 Stars).  It is by far the best space sim on the market in that regard.  It has a very steep learning curve with a minimal tutorial (including tutorial videos and familiarization missions with scripted voiceovers).  It has a vast library of youtube videos and a dedicated community.  

It is space flight simulator style game that takes liberties with physics to make the game fun and playable (i.e. ships have a maximum speed in space, but that prevents space battles from happening at tens of thousands of meters per second and across huge distances by radar only).

There are no space legs like in No Man's Sky or Star Citizen, which keeps the user experience tighter and more streamlined.  The flight model and combat is second to none (less visceral than EVE Valkyrie but far more complex).  The ships and weapons are all well balanced.

The game is more than combat, however, as you can choose to explore the galaxy (a 1:1 simulation of the Milky Way, with distances faithfully re-created where possible), smuggle illegal goods, trade goods between systems with complementary economies (i.e. make a profit by hauling ore from an extraction economy system to an industrial economy).  With regards to exploration, no other game comes even close to Elite Dangerous.

Missions are randomly generated and generally un-inspiring.  Underlying game mechanics (called the Background Simulation, as factions vye for power over star systems) are needlessly complex.

This game is a game changer in VR.  Ship sizes come to life as you suddenly realize just how HUGE your ship is!  The largest flying ships are larger than modern nuclear submarines.  Outside of VR everything is shrunk down to fit into your screen, but in VR you are engulfed by your cockpit, which is a tiny window on a huge ship.  Planets and stars will bring tears to your eyes in VR.  I bought the Oculus for this game, and don't regret it one bit.  Worth every dollar.

review_title: INCREDIBLE - FINALLY A TRUE GAME IN VR
one_reviews_text:
Expect hundreds of hours to play. You will already need 10 or 20 hours to understand the basics and several centuries to explore 1% of the universe.
Also a very interesting VR experience if you like space or sci-fi adventures.
A must have for true gamers. Only price  (on the oculus store, but you can find the game elsewhere) is a bit expensive.

With a full setup of a HOTAS (Read: Joystick + Throttle), you are fully immersed in the spaceship flying experience. Elite Dangerous is a strong game in itself, and learning how to control your ship is going to be your first hour or so, even more so when you're doing it in VR.

Once settled in, ED offers an experience no other game can match. The VR elements really add onto this game.

Ok.  If you are well into 300+ hours into a game and you still feel there is so much more you want to do, then that is a good game.  Now I will emphasize this fact, this is not a game for a casual gamer!  If you just want to get into a spaceship and blow things up, and not care about everything else that goes into living in space, or flying a spaceship, then this is not the game for you.  This is the game for all of us that want to really go into space and get into the real nitty gritty nasty details of really being there and not having some pre-programmed set path that we must follow in order to "Progress" through a spoon fed linear game.   There are no instructions on how to play.  You learn it as you go.  Nobody is going to tell you what to do, that is what you are supposed to decide.   You want to go bounty hunting?  Go for it.  Want to become a miner taking resources from the rings of a planet, or far flung asteroids?  Go for it.   Want to be a rebel and transport illegal slaves into a star port under silence and not get caught?  You can do that too.    If you want to be like me and spend months on end (real time not game time by the way) traveling to the opposite side of the Galaxy, can you say Beagle Point, you can even do that too.   It is all up to you.    This is, I repeat not a game for the casual player.  This is the game for the dedicated soul who is not afraid to put blood sweat and tears into exploring and living in space.   

(By the way, if you really want to get the most out of this game and feel that you are there, I cannot emphasize how good this game is in Virtual Reality, with a HOTAS Joystick setup with Voice Attack running in the background taking your audible commands.  It is the best experience with everything there is to space except the cold vacuum outside your cabin, and at times you will think that is out there too.)
This is where 90% of my VR time goes.  The quintessential VR space experience!

I had this game on steam before ever having a VR headset (in fact it's the very reason I bought one). 

Now let's address some of these 1-2 star reviews that don't actually review the game itself, but instead review their own technical abilities / problematic operating system or simple lack of information. 

First off, make no mistake! this isn't a "VR expericence" (well ofc it is, but using that term kinda makes me think you're trying to put it on the same page as watching dolphins swim underwater in your VR headset...). 
It's also not a 'demo' or a quick casual arcade something... that the store is full of.. This is a full blown triple-A game! One of the few that has added VR support as an additional layer of immersion, but it holds its own even without VR. (in other words, a game that was actually developed AS a game and not as a "VR experience" - much like Fallout 4.. Skyrim.. etc are all very nice standalone games and you cannot compare them "value"-wise even to the best of the VR arcades like Robo Recall or whatnot since they're simply... not even in the same galaxy - pun intended).

So based on the above, set your expectations accordingly.. This is not something you start from your Oculus dash and casually wave your touch controllers for 10-20 minutes then go and do something else. This is a new hobby that you're picking up that will provide you with thousands of hours of entertainment. 

 - Yes, you need a Frontier account to play, since this is a MMO simulation (it has Open / Solo / Private group modes to filter the amount of people you interact with, but there's a single shared galaxy so all your interactions transfer across modes)
 - The Login button is a giant orange button on the launcher desktop app itself that opens when you start the game (don't try to find it in VR, not there!)
 - pressing F12 on the keyboard recenters your head ingame so no need to use the Oculus button
 - You need an xbox controller / Joystick to play properly
Nothing like it out there....

review_title: The best VR experience I have had.
one_reviews_text:
As I look through these reviews, every negative review comes from:
1) Someone who didn't take the time set up their controls properly
2) Someone who didn't take the time to figure out how to recenter their VR 
3) Someone who didn't take the time to look up... whatever.

Yes, there will be a steep learning curve.
Yes, there will be some effort involved figuring things out.
Yes, you will be frustrated trying to figure out how to control the game in VR, regardless of your method of control.
and Yes, there are plenty of resources out there to help you along the way.

Now, if you can get through the pain of getting things set up, you are in for the best VR experience out there, period.  
-Total freedom to explore the Milky Way, from our own solar system to a jaunt from Sagittarius A* (the super-massive black hole at the center). 
-Total freedom to be a trader, miner, bounty hunter, explorer, and any combination between. 
-Total freedom to fly a small ship, a large ship or a medium ship at your whim and desire, and equip each ship to fill any of the roles above.

As long as you are willing to put in the time.

Recommendations: 
-A HOTAS (Hand-On Throttle And Stick) is highly recommended as the number of controls you will need at your finger tips is rather numerous.
-Linking your ED account to the various third-party sites out there (helps with planning and ship configuration.
-Joining a Wing of like-minded people who can help you along in the game (gaining credits or doing missions together.. what have you) makes the game more enjoyable.
-Voice Attack (third party voice command software) to assist with common controls and tasks.

I invested $200 above and beyond the cost of the game, but you can spend much less than I did to have the same experience.... and it was an investment (HOTAS can be used with other programs as well, and that was $150 of the $200 for me as I got a better-than-average setup).

Having said all this, it was worth the time and effort many times over.

I really dislike being forced to apply a giant 10+ GB patch I don't want - I play singleplayer only, everything was working perfectly using super sampling 2.0 before the patch (note the game would not start if if wasn't patched). I'm running the game on a GTX 1080 (oc 2100 Mhz boost, 11 Ghz ram), i7 7700K (4.5 Ghz), 16GB 3200 MHz DDR4 and Win10. "If it works don't fix it", sigh... I've changed Nvidia driver from 391.35 to the good old 385.28 - it has helped a bit, but performance is still far from optimal.
Furthermore now there's no sound in the HMD headphones - to fix this I had to remove my HMD and set the Rift headphones as the primary audio device in Windows. I've got perfect sound in all my other Rift games without having to do this. 
Unless you're a great fan of Elite, I'd skip this game in it's current state (v. 3.0.5), you'll need a lot of patience to enjoy this game. Note that many other users have experienced great performance problems with 3.0.5, even with GTX 1080 Ti: https://forums.frontier.co.uk/showthread.php/409609-Poor-Performance-in-VR .
Touch controls do not work - only gamepad works (and mouse/keyboard). Sometimes gamepad seems only to work when I turn on my monitor and click on the mirror image of the game.

Most negative reviews are complaints about taking off the headset, typing, or other interactive controls that require you to see what you're doing. These reviewers must remember the game is NOT developed as, but rather built to support, a virtual reality environment. Once you set up your HOTAS, gamepad, or whichever controller you're going to use, you rely on your sense of touch to navigate your controls. I bought a PS4 Thrustmaster HOTAS for this game and while I find myself having to remap keys occasionally (I don't have to take off my headset to use the mouse...), it's really a minor inconvenience for a game not built for VR.

Elite Dangerous is absolutely stunning. I have never felt so small and insignificant in my life until jumping to another star system for a basic mission, or scrolling out of the galactic map to see where we are in the galaxy. It's a surreal feeling that really put life into perspective for me.

This is a simulator, not an arcade game. There is no hand holding, storyline, or guided missions. You choose what you want to do; Mining, trading, piracy, combat, bounty hunting, transport missions (cargo/personnel), planetary exploration in a land rover, and much more. You will find yourself, at first, looking up a lot of information and frustratingly removing your headset, but once you get the feel for it and understand your controls and mission objectives, you will have the headset on for four hours straight and forget you're a real person sitting in a gaming chair with drool coming out of your mouth (South Park, anyone?)

It's absolutely worth a good solid attempt if simulation is  your thing. If you're looking for an arcade space game, move on. Removing your headset to learn the game? I got 99 problems but learning how to play a game for the ultimate immersive experience ain't one!

review_title: Best reason to have a VR Headset
one_reviews_text:
As far as I'm concern this is the best reason to have a VR headset right now.  This is a full fledge PC Game with actual gameplay dept, and systems to keep you engage for hundreds of hours if not more.   


Long story short: this is not a gloryfied demo.

The star is for interesting VR experience which is rather good at first glance. With that said it is full of bugs, crashes and unreal content which seems to have been written by  a very hands off and silver spooned team. Obviously no one with any trade or business experience was part of the development of the fantasy economy the game revolves around.  Imagine a game written by teenagers for teenagers.  
There is of course a real store in the game where you can spend real money to color your pretend ships or avatar(not the pretend currency because thats not very profitable). Its farmville in VR with a splash of star trek without comon sense.

I wanted to wait a while to review this as anything with overwhelming 5* reviews should be questioned without the honeymoon passion. For the record, I do like this game, but I can see why a lot of folks would not. To start, a steep learning curve and the training missions are harder than what you can expect right out the gate, but necessary for familiarization and even as refreshers. Once you get a handle on things and start your first flight the euphoria, and confusion, of freedom sets in. Then you learn a mistake the hard way and eject. Then you learn more the hard way. Wash, rinse, repeat until you have a good solid grasp on what to do and even then you can get too comfortable/cocky. There is a very good chance to get bored and move on, but luckily you can just change your mode of play. You were a trader? Buy a fighter and start hunting bounties. Run a taxi service. Become a pirate. The fact that it's open ended will always give a reason for "just one more mission," but I can see where it would lose the appeal to do so especially once the grind for credits or rank sets in. That said, I have to say just the atmosphere itself in VR is enough to give this game a try.

Final words: Fuel Rats are your friends!

This is the game I purchased VR for, and it did not disappoint.  When coupled with VoiceAttack, an HCS Voicepack, and a joystick and throttle, the VR experience that this game delivers is second to none.

This is not only the most complete space simulation game on the market it's almost certainly the deepest and most complex VR game by a very wide margin. However that complexity does mean you will need to devote some serious time to getting to grips with it.

To play it properly in VR you will need a HOTAS joystick & throttle system for sure - get a cheap Thrustmaster HOTAS X if you are just starting out. You will also need to DO ALL OF THE TUTORIAL MISSIONS! If you don't you will be completely lost once you enter the game itself. Even then you will spend a week flying around bumping into things and cursing the developers for making it so hard.

But after that, you will LOVE this game. It's amazing. There is nothing that comes even vaguely close to it, especially in VR. But yeah, it's a SIMULATION, not just a pick up and shoot game, so keep that in mind!

review_title: Hands down best VR experience I've had

This game won't hold your hand, you are the commander of your own ship and the milky way galaxy is your playground. You can choose to trade, or you can choose to hand-craft your vehicle for dogfighting. You can be a pirate, or an explorer. You can even choose to be a miner. Or do all of the above. There's so many ways to play Elite Dangerous and after 600 hours, I still feel like I'm just scratching the surface. review_title: Not a VR-first experience, and it shows
one_reviews_text:
Since Elite Dangerous is in the Oculus Store, you would expect that you can just install the game and play it.  Unfortunately, this is not the case.

If you use Touch, which comes with every new Rift, then you start each game looking through the floor while the game menu floats above your head.  Elite doesn't detect that anything is wrong, instead you have to Google the solution, and you find out that you need to press F12 each and every time you start the game.

Text is blurry, and the comms panel is very difficult to read. When viewing mission boards, the load time becomes frustrating because you can't look at anything but that loading screen.  Why these aren't loaded behind the scenes when you dock, I have no idea.

The game will not adapt its graphics to keep a constant 90fps, instead you have to manually adjust graphics settings if your GPU isn't keeping up.  Not even the "VR" graphics settings do this.

Aside from the VR aspects, Elite feels very much like an MMO with many of the appealing aspects removed.  There is no in-game story to speak of.  I wanted to like this because it involves spaceships, and Privateer was one of my favorite games growing up.  But there's just not enough here.  And too many MMO time sinks.

One thing going in to this game every new player should realize is that it is a space sim. You don't have a specific objective, you do not have a player centered story. What you do have is an actual galaxy sized galaxy to explore with never before seen content everywhere. You make your own story, you make your own path and you decide for yourself what is important. Most games that attempt this end up feeling bland or because of the massive amount of content the content it has ends up feeling empty. Not this game, ED: Horizons feels like a thriving galaxy. 
Not at all beginer friendly and that is honestly what makes it amazing. Once you get past the initial phase of running into everything and making every mistake possible, you'll find yourself doing things that are amazing, and discovering new mistakes you didn't think were possible.

review_title: Reason I bought the Oculus Rift

You have to love space sims to fly back and forth from system to system, but the world truly is your oyster and you choose just what kind of career you want.  Pirate, Luxury cruise liner pilot, commodities dealer, Hunter, military pilot, it goes on.   Just sit in he cockpit of a ship and take a look around.  The detail is amazing.

With over 300 hours logged I have been a trader, a smuggler a pirate and a bounty hunter. I have explored uncharted systems, flown through black holes skimmed a thousand stars to refuel. .
And for most of it.. I was mind numbingly bored playing only to pass the time.I have tried to like this game, I REALLY tried.
This is a wonderful tech demo, but it is FAR from a game. Its a slow mind-numbing experience of poorly mixed game mechanics with hundreds of hours of tedium in between rare moments of fun.
My advice, Just watch other players condensed videos on youtube, its a far more enjoyable experience. Let some one else spend weeks at a time grinding resources and entire weeks flying to out of the way systems chasing what little content the game actually offers.
Elite is technically impressive but utterly lacks soul or anything to drive a player beyond the acquisition of credits.
In open, you are forever at the mercy of the meta player. Three times, I have built a ship to what I thought was a decent level, only to be killed in seconds when I dared to play in open by a sealclubber with an "engineered" ship which while the same model as min can easily have 5x the firepower of my modest craft.
Now more than ever the game discourages the new player. The rewards are thin, while the risks are immense. The only solution to this is to play in solo, and take the shallow experience for what it is.
There is no point to most of the community goals, the "story" takes place outside of the game. Seriously, when I criticised the lack of meaningful content I was told to read the Reddit as that's where the story is... The reddit... seriously... I should not have to trawl the internet in order to try and find some measure of value from this game.

review_title: Truly terrific, but not easy to learn
one_reviews_text:
First off - I have been a fan of the original Elite when it came out in 1984 and was overjoyed when I heard about the Kickstarter campgain for a current-technology relaunch.


What Frontier came out with has the same immersive, open play atmosphere as always - there is no set goal, no defined storyline you HAVE to follow, you do whatever you please and let the world evolve around you.

The flying experience in a number of different "realistic" ships, or the driving around on planets with your surface vehicle is a simply terrific experience.

However, the realism has a downside. If you want to really master flying like Han Solo (yes, you totally can!) you must be able to control a number of functions - a lot more than your normal game pad has buttons for.

I compromise by using the gamepad and keyboard controls that I can find blindly, even though that does break the immersion a bit. Touch control is yet too unprecise/too slow to be used in the heat of battle!

As a piece of advice to those who found the game impossible to play - by all means, please learn the basic controls in desktop mode (In the Oculus App, right-click and select "Play in desktop mode"). Only when you feel you are familiar with the functions, and have a button definition that works for you, switch to using the Oculus. It may be a longer process and require some effort before you get the full reward, but believe me it is totally worth it.

The game does look superb in VR, boasting an impressive sense of scale. However, the scale works against you, causing long travel times where nothing happens, and a lack of human opponents. 

With a bit of effort from the developer, this could be a superb title but right now, despite being a  solid VR showcase, this game is feels like it needs some work to smooth off the rough edges.

But once you are actually sitting in the pilot seat, it changes everything.

You're not looking at it from a 3rd party perspective. You are actually the pilot and you need to learn all about what the dashboards around you are all about. You can stand up and walk around your cockpit, though the early ships are a bit of a tight squeeze.

You can travel at your leisure to over 400 billion star systems, some of which have still yet to be discovered & if you find them, you can have your name permanently attached to them. If you get tired of flying around, you can land on a planet and travel around in your SRV and collect some resources you'll need for future upgrades.

If you prefer to fight, then you can upgrade to a battle ship and fight until your hearts content. You even get paid for doing it for missions as well as any bounties they have.

You do what you want, how and when you want, however:

It's a grind to gain achievements and the learning curve in every aspect of this simulator can be overwhelming. You must also have a lot of time to play it or at least understand that it is something that never ends and will likely take months to years to reach top levels.

This is the best VR experience right now and the absolute best experience ever for space enthusiasts. I want more people to enjoy this experience, but I can't recommend it because so many people won't get past the learning curve in the first few hours of play time.

I spent now a couple of hours in Elite Dangerous VR, maybe 15- 20. I know - for an expert almost nothing. The question is if I really want to spend more.

I even bought a HOTAS flight stick for this. And the feeling of sitting in a space ship, cruising between galaxies, is fantastic and real. The first 1- 2 hours might drive you mad. Landing on a space station is a pain in the ***. But then you master this, then the next thing, and soon you fly with elegance.

And then? You can trade, bounty hunt, mine asteroids, even be a tourist ship. And then there´s the neverending hunt for improvements on your ship.

Besides that - not much. The universe feels real, but also very empty. No settled planets, just some trade stations on barren rocks. 

I think I will return from time to time to Elite, but only to relax, cruise a bit between the stars and get that great feeling of sitting in your ship. But investing too much time - I think not.

By the way: I played the original back then on a Amstrad CPC. Funny enough, even with the incredible VR surroundings, it kind of feels the same like 1989.

review_title: Best, real Game for VR - a blast!
one_reviews_text: Elite Dangerous is ambitious, big, breathtaking and most of all: The best, real game for your VR HMD! Played more than 400 hours on Steam, added the game now to my Oculus Home Library too, and look forward to gain additional hundrets of hours. See you in the void, Commanders!

This game lets you truly experience the immensity of space! As a first-person cockpit experience it is quite mild on the nausea, apart from when driving fast on planets in your rover. The game is unforgiving in its challenge. There is no story, no checkpoints, nothing to guide you on your way. Instead it places you smack-bang in the persona of a dirt-poor 'Harmless' rookie in a tiny ship and a fantastically detailed space simulation. Everything from a live galactic economy in human-inhabited space, haunting hints of aliens on distant stars, pirates, evil players (if you play in "Open"), mining the rings of gas giants for rare metals, ferreting out profitable trade routes or mercenary work for superpower fleets, join a guild to actually influence the galactic politics, or spend real-time months exploring out far past the galactic core, where the contrast to the bustle of the human "bubble" creates a powerful feeling of the explorer's solitude. All in a painstakingly correct physical replica of the whole 400 billion star galaxy (the constellations are correct when at Sol, because all the stars really are in their positions), planetary orbits are realistic, gravity, planetary surfaces, and all the stellar star types from O-types to black holes (including gravitational lensing!) are represented faithfully. Above all it is a wondrously beautiful experience in the Rift. The feeling of a space station's size is exhilarating in the Rift, the sharp contrasts of deep space pops out magnificently, the planets and stars are beautiful (and realistically rendered). For an extra colourful experience, try flying out to the Horsehead nebula to examine it close up!

By hook or crook, gain the money to kit a killer bounty hunting ship, super-size space trader or fully outfitted deep-in-the-void exploration ship. Claw your way to "Elite" status in combat, trading and exploration. Or enter "Close Quarters Combat" mode for immediate fast paced PvP action in a battle arena.
If you've got the hardware, i.e. big rig and peripherals, Elite is probably the best VR experience currently available. A very steep learning curve, but the time spent is well worth it.

Not sure why a few are having issues, it's clearly something on their system as Elite runs great for me and virtually all other players.  The VR experience is second to none, the sale is amazing.  Driving your SRV up to a base or huge ship, like the Anaconda or Corvette, it's amazing.  Seemlessly going from driving to flight is incredible.

Whilst Frontier has crafted an undoubtedly stunning VR experience, with satisfying mechanics for flight, combat and (mostly) travel, they still have two major problems. The first is their highly deficient attitude to multiplayer. Terrible P2P match-making tech makes any multiplayer play unreliable at best, and impossible at worst, as it's a complete lottery whether or not you'll end up in the same instance as your friends, even when grouped up. Not only that, but Frontier refuses to implement a proper in-game player groups system, meaning organising any coordinated play from within the game has to be done via a 'friends list' and the tiny 4-man 'wings' mechanic. To top it all off, there is no player-to-player trading mechanic or money transfer system, and the in-game markets only allow trade of mostly useless 'commodities', not the actual ships, modules, ammunition and so on which are actually useable by the players. These last two decisions are utterly bizarre in the context of what is supposed to be a 'sandbox' game with trading as a major feature.
Missions are the second major problem; although they have been improved since the release of the game, they still feel barebones. The missions system is important because it's deeply embedded in the 'background sim' factions mechanic, which is the only meaningful way in which players can affect the galaxy they play in. But there are two serious issues. The first is that mission lists in stations still often come up with sparse pickings. There's no reason for this; just set a bottom limit which means there will always be something to do when a player logs in. The second is a complete lack of inventiveness. Missions could be a showcase for the amazing core gameplay, from stealth & landing/scooping mechanics (sneak up to enemy base and steal some data/cargo) to combat strategy (introduce some cool settings e.g. ship graveyards/abandoned stations/shipyards/asteroid bases, and vary the objectives a little). Maybe someday...
